articles.title: About Me
articles.contents:
Scout is a graduate student in the Masters of Environmental Data Science Program at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management at the University of California, Santa Barbara. In 2018, she received her Bachelor‚Äôs Degree from Harvard University, where she studied Integrative Biology and Energy & the Environment. At Harvard, Scout led consulting projects for nonprofit organizations with the Harvard College Conservation Society and conducted ecological research. After an internship in which she managed beehives which reduce human-elephant conflict and protect agriculture, her interest shifted from ecology to human-environmental systems and conservation conflict resolution.
Scout is interested in studying the environment in the complex way that it exists in relationship with human populations. As such, she has spent the last 3 years working on urban food systems in Oakland, California with nonprofit groups No Kid Hungry and FoodCorps. Her work expanded access to healthy school meals for Oakland students. Scout believes that every person has the right to nutritious, culturally-appropriate food. She oversaw food system programs by managing procurement, participation, and waste data;she plans to use data science to transform human-environmental systems, especially food systems, to be more sustainable and equitable.

articles.title: Scout's CV
articles.contents:
Education
The Bren School of Environmental Science and Management at the University of California Santa Barbara Masters, Environmental Data Science Santa Barbara, California; current
Harvard College B.A., Integrative Biology; Secondary, Energy and the Environment Cambridge, Massachusetts; May 2018
Awards and Honors
UC Santa Barbara Merit-Based Academic Scholarship: 2021
Princeton in Africa Fellowship Finalist: 2020
Food Corps Alumni Council Member: 2019
Adams House Peter Cai Award: 2018
Harvard Center for Public Interest Careers Harvard Clubs Summer Community Service Fellowship Recipient: 2018
Harvard Graduate School of Education Opportunities in Education Fellowship Recipient: 2017
Harvard College Weissman International Internship Grant Recipient: 2017
Presentations
Leonard S, Vitorino, J. (2019 March). Teaching Stone Soup. Oral Presentation at FoodCorps Mid-Year Gathering for ‚ÄúFoodChats‚Äù symposium.
Leonard S. (2019 April). Financial Aid Story. Oral Presentation at the San Francisco Coelebration of Scholars for Harvard Alumni.
Work Experience
Share Our Strength: No Kid Hungry Campaign | Oakland Unified School District Breakfast After the Bell Specialist  | Oakland, California. | 2019-2020.
Program assessment and implementation across 50 OUSD schools for No Kid Hungry‚Äôs Breakfast After the Bell, which strategically ensures more free-and-reduced-lunch-eligible students have access to breakfast
Maintained grant compliance, developed qualitative and quantitative program measures, wrote analytic reports for funders on behalf of 25 schools which received funding for Breakfast After the Bell programming
Creative problem solving and support around various programmatic challenges at multiple levels, relying especially on building interpersonal relationships with stakeholders at the school and district level and strong communication skills

The Periodic Table | Bartender | Emeryville, California. | 2019-2020.
Familiarized myself with history, science, brewing operations, and cultural significance of more than 30 sake varieties, as well as Japanese spirits and California craft beer
Provided friendly, professional, and knowledgeable customer service to bar patrons
Managed and served the bar independently; carried out opening and closing procedures, as well as problem-solving technological, culinary, and customer service challenges

FoodCorps | AmeriCorps Service Member | Oakland, California. | 2018-2019.
Completed 1700 hours of service in 2 school communities as the sites‚Äô food and garden educator, serving students, their families, teachers, cafeteria staff, and administrators in fostering a schoolwide culture of health
Developed culturally-relevant, hands-on health curriculum to foster healthy habits, reinforce science standards, and increase accessibility to nutritious foods and the outdoors; taught PK-5th grade students
Convened diverse stakeholders to build strategic partnerships in the community to mobilize change in school gardens and cafeterias; generated student choice in cafeteria culture by creating and implementing Socratic seminars
Competitively chosen for National Alumni Council to continue supporting FoodCorps alumni in connecting with professions and professionals which support youth hunger-fighting initiatives, school food, policy, and agriculture

Atlantic White Shark Conservancy | Summer Fellow | Chatham, Massachusetts. | Summer 2018.
Secured grant funding for an added internship position through the Harvard Center for Public Interest Careers
Led new partnerships with the Cape Cod Fishermen‚Äôs Alliance, Northwest Atlantic Seal Research Consortium, and CARE for the Cape and Islands to communicate holistic messaging about the Cape‚Äôs environment and history
Communicated ongoing Great White Shark population research and safety information, as well as other science with accessible exhibits designed using Adobe and Microsoft programs, as well as spoken presentations

Adams House, Harvard University | Assistant to the Building Manager | Cambridge, Massachusetts. | 2015-2018.
Greeted dormitory residents and community with warmth and helpfulness as they entered the building and retrieved their mail; completed administrative tasks for dormitory building operations with efficiency and organization
Maintained safe, secure entry procedures to ensure the safety of the dormitory building and resident community
Provided excellent and efficient service; logged arrived mail and sent email reminders for pick-up, problem-solved with Harvard building maintenance staff around infrastructural and operational events for Adams House students
